title: Colton Gearhart
text:
Probability ‚Äì Ball State University












The concepts of probability are of great importance in a wide variety of applications. The theory of probability, as the foundation upon which the methods of statistics are based, should command the attention of those who what to understand as well as apply statistical techniques. This course, therefore, is a required course for those who want to major in statistics or actuarial science and is an excellent course for those who are in mathematics, business, and other allied fields. Click here to access the materials!

title: Colton Gearhart
text:
Mathematical Statistics ‚Äì Ball State University












Mathematical statistics is the study of how to deal with data by means of probability models. It grew out of methods for treating data that were obtained by some repetitive operation such as those encountered in games of chance and in industrial processes. These methods soon found application in such diverse fields as medical research, insurance, marketing, agriculture, chemistry, and in industrial experimentation. This course is, therefore, a required course for statistics and actuarial science majors and is an excellent course for those who may need in their work statistical methods at a reasonably sophisticated level. Click here to access the materials!

title: Colton Gearhart
text:
Data Visualization ‚Äì Ball State University






Data visualization allows people to better understand data via visual perception. This course is designed to introduce students to the principles of effective visualization design, including basics of human perception, tailoring visualizations to the data at hand, and avoiding common visualization pitfalls. Course activities will give students practical experience designing visualizations to communicate information to their audiences. Click here to access the materials!

title: Colton Gearhart
text:
Quantitative Reasoning ‚Äì Ball State University












This course covers aspects of personal finance, probability, and statistics. This course will allow students to use a variety of fundamental mathematical skills to analyze situations not typically covered in a traditional sequence of mathematics courses. Students will develop problem-solving skills enabling students to be capable and productive leaders and citizens. Click here to access the materials!

section: Elementary Statistics ‚Äì Columbus State Community College
text:
Elementary Statistics ‚Äì Columbus State Community College












This course is designed to acquaint students with statistical methods used in gathering and analyzing data. It also serves as an introductory business statistics course. The course includes survey methods, graphical displays of data, descriptive statistics, the Normal distribution, basic concepts in probability and simulation, sampling distributions and the Central Limit Theorem, confidence intervals, significance testing, correlation and linear regression, and forecasting with exponential smoothing. Click here to access the materials!

text:
Gibbs Sampling Simulation ‚Äì Research






This paper discusses how a variety of actuarial models can be implemented and analyzed with a Bayesian approach using Gibbs sampling, a Markov chain Monte Carlo method. This approach allows a practitioner to analyze complicated actuarial models by reducing them to simpler, more manageable models. Furthermore, general properties of Gibbs sampling are discussed through a simulation approach. Click here to continue reading!

title: Colton Gearhart
text:
Climate Change ‚Äì Data Visualization






This project takes NOAA data to visualize the affect of climate change on minimum and maximum daily temperatures, as well as precipitation levels, over time for three different locations around the world. With the collected data, the data visualization process from start to finish is explained and demonstrated at each step building up to the final visuals. Click here to view the project!

Computation Methods in R ‚Äì Mini Course






In this mini course we will be exploring the use of computing and non-parametric method in statistical practice. This will look like a set of general programming and computing topics and methods. This will require that we use a statistical programming language in sophisticated ways, and the module will specifically explore techniques for advanced programming in R.
